Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Sean was lying about the body, but he was very scared.  He constantly worried about what? Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n>{<n>  userChoice: "A",<n>  correctResponse: "B"<n>} <n>```<n><n>### Input, multiple choice:A woman named Linda is not a woman  if ___________. Choices: A: she is a dog B: she likes puppies C: she owns a dog  D: she is a female E: she is a male<n><n>### Response, multiple choice:<n>```javascript<n>[<n>    { <n>        "correctChoiceId" :  "B", <n>        "message": "Linda is a woman because she likes puppis"<n>    }, <n>    {<n>        "correctChoice":"C",<n>        "message":"Linda is not a woman because she owns a dog...etc." <n>    }, <n>]<n>```<n><n>## Conclusion:<n><n>The task you performed was for [Demonstration](https://github.com/Kiwi008/Exercism-JavaScript-Tutorials/tree/master/demm)<n>

Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		A: D<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>1: The body's skin is the largest organ in animals. The purpose of the skin is to minimize the impact of injuries or discomfort, due to exposure to harmful external factors, including hot or cold, chemicals, disease, sunlight, water, and abrasion. The skin protects and insulates while also acting as a sensory organ. The skin also allows for the generation of vitamin D from cholesterol when sunlight is used for it, and it can also maintain body temperature through the use of sweating in hot environments, through the formation of frost on exposed skin when exposed to extremely cold environments, and by maintaining the temperature for homeostasis of the body in hot environments and cold environments. (Due to its sensitivity to the environment, skin is particularly vulnerable to infections or irritants).<n><n>2: <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Letters are sometimes delivered by hand through one of these. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write the appropriate response, either "Letters are sometimes delivered b__a_ hand through one of these.", which is the correct answer based off of the inputs provided.<n><n>### Reason:<n><n>In line `Letters are sometimes delivered __a___ hand through one of these.` we need to determine in which line the word `Letters` is located, in order to retrieve the correct answer.<n>We can calculate this value by using the word_index function.<n><n>### Output:<n>`Input:Letters are sometimes _________ hand through one of these.[A-E]<n><n>Output:A: delivered by hand B: by a hand C: delivered B_a_ hand D: by hand E: delivered hand D_by hand F: ___________ __a_ hand<n><n>Output:Answers A: by hand B: by ___hand by a:hand C: letter by a hand D: ____ delivered hand E: hand ______ letter by`<n><n>### Run: Run the script at https://www.inputoutput.ch/jassijavasolutions/test.php<n><n>![](http://i.stack.imgur.com/V6Cs8.png)<n><n>### Solution<n><n>```javascript<n>(function() {<n>	var letter, word_index, word_index1, str, words, word;<n><n>	letter = (document.getElementById("answer1").value);<n><n>	word = str = "Letters are sometimes";<n>	word_index = ( word_index = str.indexOf(letter, word_index!== -1? word_index + 1 : 0 );<n><n>	console.log(word_index);<n><n>	words = str.split(" ");<n>	return;<n>}).call(this);<n>```<n><n>### Output<n><n><img src="http://i.imgur.com/6VYF2s8.jpg" width='80%'><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:In the middle of the day what will someone do because of being hungry? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		Choice: D: have lunch<n><n>### Justification: Since lunch is a meal served and eaten around midday. We know this must be the answer.<n><n>### Input:(Cont.) If they did not have a schedule of what to do, what would they be doing? Choices:  a: not doing what they are told b: eating lunch<n>Answer: B: eating lunch.<n><n>### Response : A: not doing what they were told. Not having a schedule is equivalent to not knowing what to do next.<n><n>### If they ate lunch and needed more because they are hungry, what could they do at the same time in the middle of the day? Choices:  B: working C: resting D: sleeping<n>Answer: C: resting<n><n>### Response:: Since they are a bit hungry, they can wait for their next meal which is lunch but, they decide to relax while they wait. We know this must mean that they can decide to work while they wait since they should be hungry and want to wait on the next meal.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		A<n>### Justification: You need apples from a different country in order for them to be imported products. Thus they would need to come from somewhere other than the USA.<n><n>### Input (Example): What of a material could be called tissue that would not be of that kind in nature? Choices:  a: Paper  b: Wood  c: Leather  d: Fabric  e: Cement<n><n>### Response (Example): A: paper<n><n>### Example response: What of a material could you call tissue would it be? Choices: A: Cement B: Paper C: Wood D: Leather E: Fabric <n><n>### Response(Example): A: Cement<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Complete what was asked in the sample problem.<n><n>### Example:<n>Input: <n>This is what you are given: <n><n>- A: ohio <n>- B: washington<n>- C: alaska<n>- D: canada<n>- E: flowers<n><n>You want to know where in America an item would be imported from. <n><n>### Example answer:<n><n>- D: cananda

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Your code should have the following structure:<n>```<n>```<n><n>#include <stdlib.h><n>#define INFINITY -99999<n><n>int a[5][5];<n>int b[5][5]; // size of matrix<n><n>main() {<n><n>// read lines<n><n>// solve<n>int i,j,k,temp,row,index,ans;<n>int flag = 0;<n>int r=2,c=2;<n>map<int,int> count;<n><n>// check if solution found is optimal<n>if(r+c == b[row][cc])<n><n>printf("\nSolution is optimal");<n><n>else if(r+c > b[row][cc] && c==0)<n>{<n><n>	k=0;<n>	for(i=0; i<r+1;i++)<n>	{<n><n>		if(a[i-2][col] + a[rows+1][col]<b[row][col])<n>		{<n><n>	i=k;<n>	k=r;<n><n>	}<n><n>	k++;<n>	}<n><n>}<n><n>scanf("%d %d",&r,&c);<n>scanf("%d",&row);<n>scanf("%[^, ]",&count[2]);<n><n>switch (count[2]) {<n>	case 0:<n>		break;<n>	case 1:<n>		c++;<n>		break;	<n>	case 2:<n>		r++;<n>		break ;<n>	case 3:<n>		c=0;<n>		break; <n>	case 4:<n>		r=0;<n>	<n>	}<n>scanf("%d ",&index);}<n><n>main() {}}<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Diving off a cliff for a cartoon character often ends in comedic what? Choices:  A: exhilaration B: dismemberment C: spinal injuries D: getting wet E: splats<n><n>### Response:		Diving off a cliff often ends in ______.<n><n>### Input:"Why did the ____ take a boat?" Choices:  A:"Hippo" B:"Zebra" C:"Monkey" D:"Bird" E:"Swan"<n>Answer: A:"Hippo""<n><n>## Solution to Task (11/30/2017 @ 7:27 PM)<n>```python<n>class TextAnswer(object):<n>    def __init__(self,question,answer):<n>        self._question = question<n>        self._answer = answer<n>        self._question_text = None<n><n>    def get_question(self):<n>        return self._question<n><n>    def get(self):<n>        self._answer_string = self._answer.lower()<n>        print self._question_text<n>        print self._answer_string<n>```<n>## Input:Diving off of a cliff for a caharacter is often met with what?<n>```python<n>question = "Diving off of a _____ is often met with dismemberment"<n>question_string = str(question)<n>question_text = question_string[2][:-1]<n><n>print "Question"<n>print question_text<n>print "\n"<n>```<n><n>```python<n>def get_question(self,str):<n>  if (len(self._question_text)):<n>    print question_text<n>    print self._answer_in<n>  else:<n>    question_text = str<n><n>def process(self):<n>  if type(question_string) == type(str):<n>    get_question(question_string)<n>  else:<n><n>```<n><n>```<n>

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:There's a lot to reproducing, but it begins and end with new life by giving what? Choices:  A: overpopulation B: birth C: presents D: propagation E: fun<n><n>### Response:		Birth<n><n>Input: When you give something away, when is its ownership passed to the recipient? Choices: <n>1. A: after they lose it<n>2. B: after you agree to give it away<n>3. C: after you receive the money<n>4. D: After you lose it<n>5. E: after they lose it or after you get rid of it<n><n>Answer: 2. B: after we agree to give it away

I call him and it's his phone ringing. He's going to pick it up because he's at home. Then I say, "How are you?" <n>When he asks me, I say, "What's your phone number?" and he gives it to me. I add the letters O and N to the end of his phone number to make it a symbol. He says the letters PH ON E.<n><n>### Response Example 1:<n>Answer:  You write the letters PH ONE<n><n>### Task 2:<n>Talking on the phone is a popular method of staying in touch with others. This task demonstrates multiple methods of talking on the phone.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:If I screw a chain ring onto something, what am I fixing? Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Code:<n>```javascript<n>const complete = (question, correct){<n>    Question.where(q1=>q1.question === question.question) //find the question<n>   .then(results => results[0]) //find the question<n>       .then(question  => question.choices) //the choices<n>       .then(choices   => choices.some(choice =>  choice.answer_code == correct))<n>       .then(choice => ({answers: [choice.answer_text].join(", ")}))<n>       .then(answers =>  {<n>            console.log(answers) //log the answers<n>            return true; //return true<n>        });<n>}<n><n><n>const question1 = new Question({<n>   question: "where could you find some plumbining that would not be  of use to you if  you are thirsty  "<n>})<n><n>const question2 = new Question({<n>    question: "when a person is beginning work  what aren't they  doing yet  "<n>})<n>const question3 = new Question({<n> question: "screw a chain ring  onto someting  what are  they  fixing  "<n>})<n>```<n>### Complete:

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The garage had light sensors and automatic doors, what kind of house was it? Choices:  A: modern house B: building C: townhouse D: neighbor's house E: downtown<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is C: "House" is a building.<n><n>### Input<n>A warehouse had a broken alarm system, why was it not safe? Choices: 1. A: The workers could enter the building unnoticed.  2. B: It was not known if there was a person inside.  3. C: It would have been less of a nuisance if it were not replaced.  4. D: You can see through the walls. E: The doors were not functional.<n><n>### Response<n>The answer is A: The workers could access the building and steal, and/or destroy the goods without being able to catch anyone because of the broken alarm system.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>A store clerk sold a box of paper to a kid who didn’t have enough money for the item. What was happening?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>**Answer:** The clerk made a deal with the child by not charging for the item.<n><n>### Example:<n>The price was reduced so the child could afford the item. Also, the child could afford the box, and the clerk could sell the box.<n><n>### What is the problem and how do we know?<n>The child has not enough money to pay for the item.<n>### How do we know it's a problem?<n>The child does not have enough money. We can see this in the story.<n>### Response: <n>The price of the box of paper was reduced so that the child could afford the paper.<n><n>The store clerk reduced the paper’s price by $2.00. The child did not have enough money for the paper. The clerk gave the child the paper and reduced a lot of money in order for the child to pay for the paper.<n><n>### Rules:<n>When I give you enough money to cover the item's price, can you please take the item? <n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What are you hoping to do when listening to an expert speak? Choices:  A: learning B: fatigue C: mercy D: empathy E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		<n>B, or C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>In the first instance, when they are thirsty, the person is not doing the activity where the plumbing is not required. It doesn't matter which one.<n><n>In the second instance, the person is not in the restful state yet. It doesn't really matter what activity is required.<n><n>In the third instance, the person is learning. This is the only reason you will hear a person in an expert setting learning. You could say A, then B. The most likely answer here is B.<n><n>In the fourth instance, the empathy or anxious response won't be the one you need to choose for B. It's A<n><n>In the fifth instance, they are learning or empathizing. The choice doesn't matter. <n><n>In the sixth instance, they are not in the task. All of the choices could apply.<n><n>Note: The answers to each of the questions given have to be B, C, D or E. B and D are correct in two of the questions.<n>

Choices:  A: jerusalem B: texas C: middle east D: china E: india<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>C:<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Input: An example of an appliance might be: Choices:  A) the kitchen sink B) the refrigerator C) the water faucet D) the lawn mower E) the microwave<n><n>## Demo:<n>Input: Which of the below is not a kitchen appliance? Choices: 1) A 2) B 3) C 4) D E) None of the above<n><n>## Answer<n><n>E.<n><n>## Question:<n>Input: A ___ person would be referred to as ____. Choices:  A ) computer literate B ) human C ) machine<n><n>## Demo: <n>Input: If a person is not human they are D. Choices: 1 ) not computer literate 2) a computer 3) computer illiterate 4) human<n><n>## Answer:<n>A.<n><n>## Question<n>Input: What is used to measure how large an area is? Choices: 	A: a computer B: a device C: a machine D: a tool E: a tool<n><n>## Demo: Input: How does someone measure tools? Choices: 3) A 4) B 5) C 6) D 7) E<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input<n>Input: What is the tool in the middle a tool of? Choices: A) a computer 2) a machine B) a device C) a device<n><n>### Demo<n>Input: Is a person not a computer? Choices: 2) No 3) Yes 4) A 5) B<n><n>### Answer<n>C<n><n>## Question: What are some products of computers?<n><n>## Instruction<n>Input: List as many of the products of a computer as you could name. Choices: A) Windows Phone B) smartphone C) mobile phone D) a computer<n><n>## Demo: What is the computer in the middle a product of? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The helm is not something you wear on your head. Rather, it moves the masts on what? Choices:  A: sailing vessel B: paddleboat C: ship D: motorboat E: tugboat<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is: b<n><n>### Demostration:<n>**Explanation:**<n>The correct answer does not have anything in common with the choices.<n> <n><n>### Instructions: <n>Choose the correct option below that answers the following riddle.<n><n>How much of some food do we consume in a day? Choices:  answer: A) a ton B) a pound C) an egg D) a chicken E) none of these<n><n><n>Answer:**A: A pound**<n><n>### Input<n>Which of these words cannot be used with a compass? Choices: <n><n>answer: C: All of them<n><n>### Explanation<n>The answer is a trick question. All four of the choices are technically interchangeable, and a compass can determine latitude and longitude using each of them.<n>You should avoid using a compass to find a specific physical location, since it is not capable of locating it. The term "latitude" refers to the latitude. "Longitude" refers to the longitudinal co-ordinates. The compass is capable of determining north, south, east and west direction.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:If I take my heifer out East, where's a place we might end up? Choices:  A: new hampshire B: dairy farm C: farm field D: texas E: county fair<n><n>### Response:		The only word that makes any sense is A. If we were to use any of the other words, the sentence would not make any sense. It would be incorrect because you are trying to take your animal to a place that is not a dairy farm, a farm field or dairy in any way. In the sentence, it makes more sense to stay with your farm or dairy. It does not matter where we go after, just that the cow is in the area of the farm.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What sport is the audience the loudest at? Choices:  A: show B: theatre C: hockey game D: movies E: event<n><n>### Response:		Answer: A: shows<n><n>### Output: What is unique about this country? Choices:<n><n>A: not a monarchy<n><n>B: same as any other<n><n>C: the flag<n><n>D: only 3 continents<n><n>E: 13 colonies<n><n>[Source](https://www.khanacademy.org/computing/computer-programming/python/hello-there-part)<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>### Task:<n><n>1. Create a string name variable.<n><n>    - [optional] Ask the user for a name they want to use.<n><n>    - Use their name.<n><n>2. Assign an object value type to name_variable.<n><n>3. Give the class a class name. In your case, it is called Person.<n><n>4. In your Person class you need to write the 5 statements from the list below inside the Person class.<n><n>5. A Person class must have the following 5 statements (you may create other 5 statements besides this 5).<n>   a. Define the name of the class<n>   b. Define the name of a variable that stores the value of name variable<n><n>6. Set the value of the name variable you made in step 1.<n>**It must store the name you have decided in step 2.<n>  (In your case, it’s the name of the variable that stores a person’s name).<n>     ```<n>       my_name = Hello! my name is John Doe<n>     ```<n>        - [optional] Create a class in the same Person that prints Hello! my name is "Name you have decided in step2".<n>         Use the name variable created in step 3 as you name in the my_name variable.<n>         <n>        - Use the same name variable you have created in step 1 to print the name of another variable.<n>         You may name it as name_variable or something different.<n>         
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:A government seeks what over it's people? Choices:  A: country B: trouble C: city D: sun E: control<n><n>### Response:		<n>Government is supposed to serve the people, not vice-versa.<n><n>### Input:(In the above instruction "The above instruction...")<n><n>### Input (1): The above instruction describes a...<n>### Input (2): There are ___ choices; you must choose exactly one.<n>### Input (3): One of the choices is: __<n>### Input (4): The correct answer is ___<n>### Input (5): The incorrect answers are ___.<n>### Response (1):<n>Instructions:<n><n>- Input:A government seeeks what over it's pepel.<n>- Response:<n>  Government is supposed to serve the peple, not vice versa.<n><n>## ☁️ Cloud Nine<n><n>In addition to task instruction, the author may add comments for the reader.<n><n>These comments help to make the task clear or provide a context to the process.<n><n>The comments for the above question:<n><n>- Response (1): This may be a practice exercise<n>- Response (2): This may also be a practice exercise
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The people wanted to take the scenic route, they chose the highway that cut through the what? Choices:  A: countryside B: united states C: beach D: atlas E: developed land<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Inside the home there is a shower, so it should be able to be found, because the shower uses water. However, it would not be useful to one who is thirsty because it does not provide water. For a thirsty person, a water fountain is a useful place to get a drink. Similarly, a water fountains is unlikely a useful place for one who is not thirsty because it may not be necessary for there to be water available. Furthermore, a plumber will be able to fix any plumbing in the home (that he finds) even if he is not thirsty. <n><n>It would be accurate to say that when a person starts work that they have not started to accomplish. However, they are resting, tired, and have not started their work. Therefore, the answer is D.<n><n>```<n><n>Input: The people wanted to take the short route; when they arrived, they decided that the highway that had cut through the atlas was the most convenient. Choices:  A. to be correct B. had cut through the at the hotel at the corner C. had cut through the beach D. is correct E. had cut through the United States <n><n>### Response<n>```<n>As previously stated, water fountains that were not useful to one who was thirsty, now they are not useful to one who is not thirs. A plumber finds plumbing work in buildings other than his own home; such as hospitals and hotels. Therefore, "what wouldn't you be of use to" could be replaced with "in plumbing that is outside it's owner's house"<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Write a response that describes what the correct answer is, and also explains how you know that the response is correct.<n>2. Your response should be written entirely in the language that you have been studying in this course<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:James used the cannon to shoot at something while seeking lunch. It was overkill.  What did he shoot at? Choices:  A: body armor B: ungulate C: bomber D: kill people E: animal<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>---<n><n># Task 1:<n>- Find the location of the nearest plumbing in case you get thirsty<n><n>---<n><n>```python<n># import required packages<n>import datetime, time, urllib.request<n>from selenium import webdriver<n>```<n><n>---<n><n>## The HTML Page: http://web.bcb.net.ro/cronometru/cron.html<n>---<n><n><n>```python<n>url_page = "http://web.bcbcront.ro/cron.html"<n>headless = webdriver.Chrome()<n>headless.get(url_page)<n><n>elem = headless.find_element_by_class_name("answer")<n>elem.click()<n><n>```<n><n>#### Response:<n><n>## A: oil refinerIES<n>><n><n>---<n><n>-----------------------------<n><n><p style="text-align:center;"><n>    <span class="fa-stack fa-3x">         <n>      <i class="fas fa-circle fa-stack-2x"></i>      <n>      <i class=fas fa-cogs fa-stack-1x fa-inverse"></i> </span><n>      <i class='fab fa-react' style="color: green; font-weight: normal"></i><n>      <i style="color: green;" class="fas fa-terminal "></i><n>    </span><n></p><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:If a person wants to buy a radio, where are they likely to go? Choices:  A: station B: every car and house C: shop D: bedroom E: space shuttle<n><n>### Response:		<n>Based upon the question, one cannot say that going to an oil refinery will help in satisfying the need for water because oil refineries require different resources like crude oil. There are places where one could obtain water on an oil refinery but this is mostly for the purpose of fire, and they are not intended to be used for drinking. Therefore, they won't produce water. On a different note, not until a person has started work, then they don't get to accomplish anything at all. For example, on a business establishment, you will find that at the beginning of day, employees are yet to start work and the only thing that they do at that moment is to go to the water fountain and have enough drinking water which they may possibly need for the beginning of the day. Therefore, the answer is E. The remaining choices are only valid during the process of work or when a person is working.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she just woke up? Choices:  A: drink tea B: thank god C: open eyes D: feel angry E: complete sentence<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>#This program asks a multiple choice question with choices of A; B; C; D; E. <n><n>import sys<n><n>answer = None<n>q = None<n><n># Prompting the user to input choices based on the answer to question<n><n>while q == "input_q":<n>    q = input("Enter 'a' to enter A, 'b' to enter B, 'c' to enter C, 'd' to enter D, and 'e' to enter E: \n")<n><n>    while q.lower() not in ["a", "b", "c", "d", "e"]:<n>        q = input("Enter answer in lowercase letters.  " + q + " is not a valid answer.")<n><n>if q == "input_a":<n>    answer = True<n>elif q == "input_b":<n>    answer = False<n>elif q == "a":<n>    print("A: oil refineries")<n>elif q == "b":<n>    print("B: wall")<n>elif q ==  "c":<n>    print("C: show")<n>elif q == 'd':<n>    print("D: own home")<n>elif q =="e":<n>    print("E: water fountain")<n>else:<n>    print(q + " is not a multiple-choice-answer.")<n>    <n>#print "choice A, B or C"<n><n>#while q == "input":<n>#    while q.lower!= "a" and q.lower!= "b" and q.lower not in ["yes", "no"]:<n>#        q = input("Input one if statement: Enter answer in lowercase letters \n")<n>    <n>#if q == "one_of_three":<n>#    print "choice A, B, or C"<n>#elif q == "yes_no":<n>#    print("Yes or No:")<n>#     <n><n><n>#print q + " is not one of the three choices"<n>#else:<n>#    print "Invalid choice! Please input a choice again."<n><n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Use the input above as a starting point to develop your own solution.<n><n>If you were to use a multiple choice response, write all the code that is the same and different from what is written here.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:I wanted  a side chair for people to visit me while I worked, where did I have it put? Choices:  A: building B: office C: library D: table E: bathtub<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A: building<n><n>You would not find plumbing in bathrooms at refineries because refineries use the flammable liquids obtained from crude oil (and thus are not made of stone or concrete). The only place you may find "plumbing" at a refinery is where they store and handle the products they obtain from crude (i.e., gasoline, diesel, and other fuels).<n><n>*<n><n>A chair is an inanimate object so by definition, something that is "not being used" at all means that "work" is not occurring. Additionally, this chair is not built nor is it in the library.<n><n>### Input 9:When a person is starting work what can't they do?  Choices:  A. Accomplish  B. Work  C. Rest   D. Be tired  E. Momentum.<n>Answer: E. Momentum<n><n>### Input<n>A person is beginning a task. The options listed represent descriptions of that task, but one of the descriptions cannot be described yet because it will not occur until the task is completed. Which one is it? Choices: A: Accomplishing B: Working C: Tiredness D: Momentum E: Resting<n><n>#### B: Working<n><n>Before you start working, you don't accomplish. You can work and you can rest, but you must be able to accomplish.<n><n>#### C: Tiredness<n><n>Tiredness will occur at the end of the completion of the task but while the task is being completed no one will be tired.<n><n>#### D: Momentum<n><n>Momentum will occur with the completion of the task.<n><n>#### E: Resting<n>Resting occurs after the work.<n><n>### Response<n><n>*<n><n>#### B: Building<n>When the person begins a task, it is not in the library because the library must already be built.<n>*<n>*<n><n>### Input Where was a person having the table put?  Choices: A. Reflection B. Table C. Building D. Office E. Library. A person was looking at their plumbing. It wasn't in their office, at their building or at their table and it wasn't at their home. Where was it?<n>#### B: Table<n><n>A reflection of a

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:If you're known to buy presents for others often you would be called what? Choices:  A: go shopping B: generous C: earn money D: have money E: gift buyer<n><n>### Response:		<n>When a person is beginning work what aren't they do yet?<n><n>### Answer:<n>D: accomplishing a small task.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>First, we ask what it could be. And we find the options, but are unaware of which one to select. This is when it is helpful to use conditional statements.<n>```<n>if you are thirsty. Then<n>if there is a wall nearby. Then<n>```<n>And we should follow along this pattern, asking multiple what ifs, like a decision tree.<n><n><n>Once we complete the sentence, we can begin to evaluate what the user might want to do.<n><n><n>It is important to realize the user has only asked for the statement, not how to get said statement.<n><n>### Author info:<n><n>### Contact info:<n>### License info

If the numbers are of differing types the program will output an error. <n><n>### Instructor-Facilitated Discussion<n>I was given a task to complete this section but I am confused on where I start and where do I work on it.<n><n>### Problem Statement:<n>Write a program that<n>- Input two or more numbers<n>- Get two or more lines of input. (The line in which the command is located should be the first)<n>- Sum the numbers and print the total number of lines read.<n>- If different number types are entered, the program will output an appropriate error message<n><n>### Instantiation:<n>Input: number 1 and number 2<n>> $ python program.py > 3 < 5<n>Output:<n>number: 3<n><n>number of lines: 2<n><n><n>### Instinct:<n><pre><n>	def main(argv):<n><n>		for num in argv:<n>			num = int(num)<n><n>			if num == False:<n>				# Error message<n>				print("No number was recieved")<n><n>			else:<n>			<n>				counter = 0<n>				result = 0<n><n>				while num!= True:<n>			 <n>					result += num<n>				<n>	print("The total is: ", result)<n><n>	print("The number of lines entered is: ", counter)<n></pre><n><n><n>### Expected output:<n>When I inputted the numbers, one was a string (number 1), the other (number 2) was an integer.<n>The output should say, "No numbers were recieved."<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Collections of atoms called molecules make up everything you can hold in your what? Choices:  A: atom B: anything C: air D: feet E: hands<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. The words "could" and "would" are considered modal verbs in English. So the sentence could be modified to answer this question using the modal verb would.<n><n>```<n>Input: Where could  you find some plumbling that would be of no use to you if you were thirsty?  <n>...<n>```<n><n>2. The question would be worded as "Where would you find some plumbign that would not be of any use to you if you <n>are thirsty?" <n><n>```<n>Input:(1)...(2) <n>...<n>```<n> <n>3. The answer would be "A: Plumbling could not be found at a place like an oil refinery because you would not be thirsty there." <n><n>```<n>A:...<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```<n>Input: When a  person  is beginning work, what are they not doing yet? Choices:(1). Choices: A: working B:  resting C:  tiredness D:  accomplishing  E: momentum <n>...<n>Choice A: A person resting (2).<n>```<n><n>4. The sentence could be modified to the question "What are not people doing when they are beginning work?"<n><n>```<n>A. A person is not resting.<n>...(3)<n>```<n><n>5. The answer would be  "A: When a person is  beginning  work, they are not resting. They are working at the beginning <n>of work."  (4)<n><n>(1). The words "could"and "would"are considered modal verbs in the English language. <n><n>(2). They are the verb form used to express conditionality.<n><n>(3)  The answer would be "When a  person  is  beginning work, they are not..."<n><n>(4). The words in italics would be added to the sentence to complete the question/answer format.<n><n>

You then have to add the 2 numbers adjacent to each other together and double their output. Then write out the code for your algorithm<n></p><n></details><n><details><summary><b>Part 2 (No Spoilers!) </b></summary><n><n><pre class="line numbers" id="Line-Numbers-1:1"><n>### Instruction<n>### Description:<n><p><n>Write a recursive function that accepts a string and a function that takes in 2 characters and produces an integer (or a string). <n><n>Input: a string named'string' and a recursive function parameterized by an integer 'n'. <n><n>Recursive Function:<n>- Returns a string named'string2', which is equal to the string'string' where, for each character, you have taken the first and last characters of the character's line number and called the function on it.<n><n>E.g, the string 'abbbcdcccdefabcdef' will be given a line number called '2' and your function. <n>It looks like this: abbbcd>cde>fbddbc>cee<n>For each character, you're taking the first and last of each characters line number and you're giving that  to your function (which is the last input). <n><n>Output: string2<n><n><n></p><n>The recursive function will be given a line of code that is similar to: <n><n><p><n>charLineNum = 0; <n>charFirstChar = FirstChar; <n>charLastChar = LastChar; <n>string2 = LineNumberFunction (charlineNum, charFirstChar, charLastChar); <n></p><n><n></details>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:How do you indicate that you agree wtih someone? Choices:  A: like more B: nodding C: by wearing rings D: concordance E: shake hands<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A) yes, you are correct B) nice to meet you C) sorry to hear that D) I do not agree E) I'm doing fine.<n><n>*This solution is intended for [Clean Code](https://www.udacity.com/course/clean-code--ud844), [Introduction to Python](https://www. udacity.com /course/python-basics--cs101, [Programming for Everybody](https://www. udemy.com/course/beginning-python-programming/)*<n><n>### Required packages<n><n>* Pip<n>* Pylint<n><n>```<n>$ sudo install pylint<n><n>$ python -m pip install pylint<n>```<n>### What are Linting errors?<n>The Python Linter is a command line program that checks your Python programs against rules that a team has already come to on writing good and elegant Python code.<n><n>### Linting Errors:<n>All linting errors can be classified into the following categories:<n><n>### 1. Syntax errors<n>Python allows you some liberties but also follows its own grammar. Anything that doesn't meet the requirements of these grammar rules is a syntax error. So Python's syntax errors fall into:<n><n>* Undefined variables<n>* Invalid expression<n>* Invalid assignment<n>* Invalid assignments<n><n>```python<n># python lint command<n>$ python -m pylint --disable-disallowed-name-paterns <filename>.py<n>```<n><n>### 3. Missing or empty line<n>It is acceptable to have 1 (ONE!!!) blank line between the module or class header and the body of the code but it is strictly prohibited to have MORE THEN (1) blank line.<n><n>```python<n>foo = 3<n><n>bar = 5<n><n>baz = 7<n>```<n>> This code is perfectly fine and makes perfect sense. Even though blank lines are generally considered harmless and not necessary to your code, they may cause problems if you're working on code with other people. Because nobody wants to work with any form of code without blank lines. Having a single blank line that breaks the code up is fine, but if the first line of your code is empty you've already violated this rule. The Linter, therefore, will flag this

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### This method provides the answer for the task:<n><n>```js<n>//function to handle multiple choice questions<n>function multipleChoice(question) {<n>const result = question.split(' ')[1]<n>return result<n>};<n><n><n>//function that makes sure to check for the correct answer.<n>function validMultiChoice(question,answer) {<n>  let myFunction = question.split(' ')<n>  const correctAnswer = myFunction.slice()<n><n>  if (correctAnswer == answer){<n><n>    console.log(`Correct answer: ${answer}!`);<n>  }<n>  else {<n>    <n>    console.log("Incorrect answer");<n>    <n>    ;<n><n>    if (myFunction.length!= 3) {<n>      <n>      console.log("Insufficient information");<n>      console.log(`Notenough information`);<n>      <n>    }<n>  }<n>}<n><n>//call function to respond and check for correct answer.<n>multipleChoice('Where could you find some plumming that would not be of value to you if you are throstric')<n>//multipleChoice('When a person is beginning work what are they not doing yet')<n>//multiple choice('Where could you find a piece of plumbing that would be of value to you<n>if a person is thirsty')<n>```

Choices:  A: lie down B: run away C: bite D: keep alive E: feel pain<n><n>### Response:		A: lie down<br><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question in less than 100 words without using more than 1-2 incomplete sentences.<n><n>### Input A: A plane is taking off to go over the ocean. The plane flies from the ground at a constant speed of 50 mph. The airport and the ocean are separated by 160 m. How much time will it take for the plane to reach the ocean if it took 50s to become airborne? The planes speed can be ignored. Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		A: carpet<n>### Criteria:The forgotten lefthanded, he found it covered is a reference to his fridge. In the last sentence of the paragraph, we are informed that "there were lefthanded leftovers", which means that leftovers were unintentionally overlooked. However they have now been "found" because they are leftovers he has forgotten. This reference is made clear by stating that they were "...quite old". This gives a sense of them being left behind, and covered in mold in accordance with the fact that they were not intentionally put in his fridge but in his carpet instead.<n>### Input:When you have been in the same position more than a month, it can become very difficult to maintain which of the following state's of being?Choices:  A: sleep B: exhaustion C: lethargy D: anger E: confusion<n><n>### Criteria:"When you have been in....." means that it is difficult to maintain being in this state of being when it was a longer period of time that one. It therefore leads toward an answer such as lethargy, confusion and/or fatigue that are answers that refer to timespan of time because these are the answers relating to being in this state for a much longer period of time. Lethargy refers to the physical fatigue of someone. Confusion is related to the mental or emotional state of a person, and confusion leads to lethargy and exhaustion. These would be the most appropriate and correct answers considering the context of the task.<n><n>### Input:"They are not always at their best, but they are always at their worst." means that they are not at their best or their worst permanently, but that they can change from being at their best to being at their worst at any given time. This can refer to someone who is always angry or sad, or always a happy, lighthearted person. They can be happy one minute, and angry the next due to a situation and then this leads to them being happy once more.<n><n>### Response:"Who is referring to these words of wisdom?"<n><n>### Response(answer):The words of wisdom that the sentence contains refer to his grandfather, and they therefore refer to the grandfather because they were given to him to help him make the correct decision. A drunk person may have lowered standards of conduct, or at least be unaware of the need to conduct themselves properly. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? I want to ask a question that doesn't have the question or answer<n><n>Response:<n>A yes or no and comment if the task is not answered correctly or not at all.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>**Issues:**<n><n>* Task1 does not have both the question and answer.<n>* Task1 should just have the question not both the question and answer<n>* Task2 doesn't tell what should be the answer<n>* You have to comment on an answer just being the question<n><n>**Fix the issues above.**<n><n>## Contributing to this work<n><n>If you want to add to, enhance, or change this project, please issue a pull request.<n><n>## Creation<n><n>* `python newTask.py`<n><n>`git add task.py`<n><n>* `git commit -m "added new task" || git commit -m "fixed task" || git commit`<n><n>`git push`<n><n>**Bare this in mind, when you add a new task, you're going to start editing task.py<n><n>* `python oldTask.py` This does not need to be done, as the old task will not be used, and will be removed in the next section.<n>* `python addTask.py` This script will add a task of your choice to the list.<n><n>`git add addTask.py`<n>**Remember, you will need to make an empty file called addTask.py and remove the file and code, in the first section above.<n><n>* `git add config.yml`<n>* `python oldAddTask.py`<n>* `git commit`<n><n>`python newAddTask.py` This will add a new task named your pick and you need to update the pick to 'oldAddTask.py'<n><n><n>## Copyright info<n>Copyright (c) 2017, Chris Choi<n>This software

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:When he touched the exposed wire he shouldn't have found it surprising that he got what? Choices:  A: see work B: shocked C: humor D: startled E: funny<n><n>### Response:		<n>* B is the only answer that is correct.<n>* The person got a shock because he touched an exposed wire.<n><n>### Input - Output<n><n>### Input<n><n>* _____ when he finished<n><n>### Output<n><n>* he should have<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>* _____ he was doing right now<n><n>### Output 2<n><n>* working<n><n>### Input-Output pair 3<n><n>* he could have done a few things<n><n>### Output-Output pair 3  <n><n>* What he couldn't do was: work
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The cow would come outside even after the storm had passed, it wouldn't leave the what? Choices:  A: meat grinder B: stable C: red barn D: gate E: green field<n><n>### Response:		<n>```JavaScript<n>var choices = ["A", "B", "C", "D", "E"];<n>  choices.forEach(function(choice) {<n>    console.log(choice);<n>  });<n>  console.log("Answer is: " + choice);<n>```<n><n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when in a race? Choices:  A: lay eggs B: eat fruit C: wrestle D: compete with each other E: draw pictures<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question asked if humans compete with each other which is an example of a plumbing question.<n><n>## Test Run<n>**Plumbing**<n><n>| Question | Answer |<n>| --- | --- |<n>| What are you doing when you’re not working? | you are resting |<n>| What can you do when you’re finished working? | accomplishing |<n>| What does a human do in a race? | compete |<n><n>The first response passed, the second response failed. The question asked if a human can accomplish something during a race and this is the right answer.<n><n>**Housekeeping***<n><n>| Question | A | B | C | D | E |<n>| --- | :---: | ---: | ---: |--: | :---: |<n>| Which one of these things is not a room in your home? | **A**|**C**|**E**|**none**|**C**,**C**|<n>| Which do you use when you walk in the door? | **B**|**A**|**D**|**C** |**C**|<n><n>The answers were found using [Charm](https://chocolate-charm.com/).<n><n>----<n><n>*[Source code](https://github.com/codingtrain/CodingTrain/tree/main/challenges/charmplumbing)*<n>*[Solution (video)](https://youtu.be/3JbNkDmBhYw)* <br><n><n>----<n><n>[![forthebadge](http://forthebadge.com/images/badges/built-for-badges.svg)](https://forthebadge-badges.herokuapp.com/)<n><n>----<n><n>_Coding train is maintained by [@ryandocherty](https://github.org/ryandocherty)(ryan.docherty@gmail.com)_.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Why would professionals playing sports not be able to compete? Choices:  A: pain B: mudslide C: sweating D: injuries E: rain<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### <n>"P.S. Have a great day!-Kimberly, Office Manager"<n><n>*Due on Monday 5/7/18 before midnight. Thank you.<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>import os<n><n>def read_text(filename):<n>    return os.path.join(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)), filename) <n>```<n><n>### Read text file.<n>```python<n>inp = open("text.txt").read().lstrip().strip()<n>answer = input(inp)<n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n>## 2 of 4<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Run the program.<n>2. Fill in the answers when asked.<n>3. You can run the program again.<n><n>### Input in file:<n>```python<n>Hi!<n>Thank you so much for your help. If things get really busy in the office, let me know and I'll come take something off your hands.<n><n>Have a great day!-Sarah, HR Director<n>```<n><n>##<n>## Instructions<n><n>```python<n><n>from random import randint<n>import os, sys<n><n><n>filename = read_text("text.txt")<n>answer = "B"<n><n>filename =filename.replace("Text","").replace("Test","").replace("Test1","").replace("Test2","").replace("Test3","").replace("Tsest1","").replace("Tesst2","")<n>file_path = os.path.dirname(filename)<n>print(". ")<n>sys.stdout.write(sys.stdin.channel.name + "\n")<n>print(file_path.replace(filename, ""))<n>print(" ".join([chr(ord(c)+randint(-2, 2)) for<n> c in filename]))<n><n>if answer == 'A':<n>    sys.stdout.write('A\n')<n>elif answer == 'B':<n>    sys.exit()<n>elif answer == 'C':<n>    sys.stderr.write('C\n')<n>elif answe == 'D':<n>    sys.write('d\n')<n><n><n>```<n><n>## Outputs<n><n>Output 1:<n><n>> 49xm.txt<n><n>

There are many schools that have electricity. <n>John doesn't live in a school, but that doesn't matter to us, because we aren't trying to find a location for John, we are trying to find where his RV can plug in and use the electricity, and if John has to go to school to plug it in, that's fine, he has many options, and he can just walk there.<n><n>### Input<n>Where is John most likely to go to wash up? However, John does have to wash up, and the best place to do so would be the washing area next to the toilet in a camping area. So if John would find a place that would be good, he would go there and wash up.

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the answer was B, then the response should be "C: retreat"<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>What is the next word in this sequence:?<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input: _________ __a__ __ b__ __ c__ __ d__ __e__ __?<n>Answer: A: 4 B: D<n><n>### Input<n>Input: 20__ __b__ __8__ __d__?<n>Answer: B: 23<n><n>### Task<n><n>You are given a word sequence of length 'n', and you are asked where the next word should go in the sequence. There is a letter for each position in the sequence.<n><n>Input: n:9<n><n>### Output<n><n>If the answer is given by the input, then output "yes" and the letter that goes there<n><n>If it doesn't matter for the sequence is completed, output "No"<n><n>Examples:<n><n>n: 9<n><n>1: a<n><n>2: b<n><n>3: c<n><n>4: d<n><n>5: e<n><n>6: f<n><n>7: g<n><n>8: h<n><n>9: i<n><n>Result: Yes, g<n><n>Result: No<n><n><n>### Input and Output<n><n>If the output is given by the input. Output yes<n><n>Output not given: answer is False<n><n>Examples:Input: n:9 Output: 1: a 3: c 4: d 7: g 9: i Result: Yes, g<n>

Implement the method in such a way that it accepts and returns values of any type. Below the method are a number of test cases to show how to use the method. Test with the input and the expected outputs. The expected outputs must match the original value, just not the same way.<n><n>### Method:<n> public static Map<Object, Object> reversemap(Collection input, Collection expected) { if (expected == input) { return input; } Map<Object, Object, Comparator> map = new LinkedHashMap<Object, Object, Integer>(); map.put(0, expected.iterator().next(), 1); expected = new HashSet<Object>(); for(Iterator<?> i = expected.iterator(); i.hasNext();) { Object o = i.next(); if (input.contains(o)) { i.remove(); set(o, input.size(), map, 2); } } return map.get(1); }<n><n>### Tests:Input:123<n>####Output:Input:456<n>####Output:Input:'A'<n>####Output:Input:[12, 1, 4]<n><n>### Assignment<n><n>*Write a test method that tests for the output returned by the method.*<n><n>*Input:Return:Input:Return:Input:[1, 2, 3, 4]<n>*input:1.2.3.4<n><n>### Assigment:<n>You were hired to debug a java program named Diner. I am using an int variable called n to count the amount of loops in the for loop. <n>4.  A line of code is an instruction to your computer. Choices:  A; speech B: writing C: phone call D: none of the choices<n>Answer: B: writing<n><n>Your name is a person who is a friend. You are also a friend to that same person. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? Choices:  A: wear shoes B: learn C: hope for peace D: have a great day. E: do well<n><n>### Response:		You do well.<n><n>### Input What is so different about an orchestra? Choices: 10 B 10 musicians. C 8 4 instruments. D 4 musicians on each instrument. E 12 people playing instruments.<n><n>### Response What is so is so different you are not.<n><n>### Comment:<n><n>Comment for your colleagues or your superior that says this will work.<n><n>Answer: The below program works properly and gives all the outputs listed above.<n><n>\begin{code}<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <regex><n>using namespace std;<n><n>int main()<n>{<n>    string str;<n>    regex re(R"(What [is|is not] [something].)", regex::icase|regex::multi_line);<n>    regex_match(str, re, regmatch_t match);<n><n>    string answer;<n>    switch (match.size())<n>    {<n>    case 1:<n>        answer = "You do well.";<n>        break;<n>    case 11:<n>        answer ="You are wrong for now.";<n>        break ;<n>    default:<n>        answer= match.prefix(1).before("\n");<n>        break;<n>   }<n><n>    cout << answer;<n><n>    return 0 ;<n>}<n>\end{code}<n><n>Comment: While this code-only answer is probably correct and useful, it will not be much help to future readers without an explanation of what it is designed to accomplish and why this approach is one that others might want to use. This answer could be improved by providing some words around the actual solution itself to explain the reasoning and solution to the asker.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. You will be rewarded by 6 students and it should be clear to them.<n><n>> #### You are one of the six students who is in a math class where the teacher gives the wrong answer when asked a question. The teacher then gives a five-minute detention to every student. Each student receives a grade of F because they can’t do the problem, but you get a detention because you are the one who brought up that the teacher has failed the class. You then receive a total of _____ grades for solving this problem.<n><n>> - A: 0  B: 3  C:1 -1  D: 7  E: 4<n><n>### How to do it:<n><n>To understand this type of input is the best way to answer.<n>The input is the one which contains the question and it will be in the format of input=<prompt><data><n>The data should tell you what can you do to solve the multiple-choice question.<n>And, the answer should be the one that is in the format of answer=<data><n>This is an example:<n>````<n><prompt>(A: 0 B: 3 C: 1 -1 D: 7 E: 4)<n>Because, the answer=3 and it's not in the format as <data><n>That means the answer is incorrect. I guess that this answer should be 0<n>````<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>Give the student a grade<n><prompt>(When a person is beginning work a good indicator is the amount of people they will be surrounded by.) This is the explanation<n><prompt>(Where could you find some plambing that would not be useful to you?) The answer is wall. because, even the water fountain is not 24/7. They are closed because they can't get water from other places.<n>````<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? Choices:  A: chess set B: strategy C: toy store D: chess game E: small case<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Solution1:<n><n>If I wanted to store chess pawn when i'm not using it, a good place for that is under the chess table if it's a large chess board. i'm planning to store under the chess table and i never use chess board that often so that it won't be a problem. i've stored it in a large case or a wooden box to protect it from being damaged or broken if i accidentally knock it to the floor.<n><n>#### Solution2:<n><n>If i wanted to store my chest when i'm not use it, i think the chest is a good place for that. that's because the chest is a sturdy wooden case that will protect my chester from damage. i also know that i'm not the only one who owned it so that it wouldn't be a problem if i store it there.<n><n>#### Solution3:<n>If I wanted to be sure i don't forget what's in my chest, how should i make note of it? Choices: <n>A: Put it in a text file <n>B: write it down <n>C: type it in a notepad<n><n>D: use it as often as possible <n><n>Answer: D<n><n>##Explanation:<n><n>Since the input says "i'm thirsty", the most common place to look for plumbing is the faucet,  which is the kind of plumbing found in a sink.<n><n>### Solution1:<n> <n>Ans: The only suitable answer in the given choices is A,B and C. A, B and C are the parts of a chess set, which is what was asked in the question.  <n><n>### Solution2:<n> <n>A: We use a chest mainly to store jewelry, clothes and other valuables. The chest is usually a good place to hide valuables because it is large and can fit many things. There are also many places to hide valuables in a chest, such as under clothes, in drawers, or behind items. Moreover, chests are usually built to last a long time and are very strong. They are not usually used much like a typical cupboard, so it is unlikely that someone would know about them unless they look for them. In the future, if I want

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some airplanes that are not being used? Choices:  A: war B: aircraft carrier C: sky D: graveyard E: crash<n><n>### Response:		A: Sky<n><n>If you like the program just let me know i'm always looking for better ideas to improve it with your feedback.<n><n>### This is a good example of when a user wouldn't get a result<n><n>### How you think you could have made it better:<n>Answer: A: Sky Choices:  A- B-<n><n>### How do you think you should improve the instructions next time:<n><n>### Things you learned today:<n>### Extra questions:<n><n>### AI/Turtle:<n>### AI:<n>Turtle's have to be programmed as well. When the user wants to start the program then you have to tell the turtle exactly what to do.<n><n>### Language:<n>### Python:<n>```<n>class HelloWorld:<n>def __init__(self, name):<n>self.name = name<n>    def greeting():<n>      print(f'''Hello {self.name}! ''')<n><n>    def bye():<n>        print(f'''Bye {self.name} ''')<n><n>greeting()<n>bye()<n>```<n>### Markdown:<n>```python<n>* Hello World<n>* Goodbye<n>```

Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:What will happen to your knowledge with more learning? Choices:  A: headaches B: bigger brain C: education D: growth E: knowing more<n><n>### Response:		 A: Headaches<n><n>### Input : How can a person not want to learn more things and want to be in a field? Choices: <n>A: Not be in a field B: Want to not learn C: Want to know<n><n>### Response :C: Want to know <n><n>### Input  : What will happen when the head is not working properly? Choices:  Choices:  A B C D. <n><n>### Response   A: headaches<n><n>### Instructions: <n>* This is the 21st century and knowledge is the most powerful possession that people can have. It is not only powerful it is almost irresistible to know things. Not all people know things but that does not mean they don't possess knowledge. <n>* Knowledge can be gained in many situations and areas of one's life for example, a person can learn about themselves by simply looking in the mirror. The knowledge acquired about oneself can be passed along to friends, colleagues and loved ones. <n>* Knowing how to do things properly is a form of knowledge. Knowledgable people want to acquire knowledge as much as possible. Knowledgeable people want to achieve as many skills as possible because this will make them unique and will set them apart. <n>* To be a master of something is to know it very well and to be able to use this knowledge in everyday skills and situations. Knowledgeable people tend to know many things in a variety of skill sets.<n>* When people feel good and are well they tend to learn more. They feel that they can do new things and that learning new things will only enlighten the mind and make it grow.<n><n><n>### Output 60 <n><n>	C: the more you know the bigger your brain will be<n>

Choices: <n><n><n>2 different answers:<n><n>A: winter <n><n>B: summer <n><n>C: winter<n><n>Answer: A: winter<n><n><n># How it works:<n>There's multiple choice questions that the bot must answer by providing the correct answer out of the choices provided.<n><n># Input:<n>A sentence is created with a multiple choice question and answers<n><n># Response:<n>A sentence is provided by the bot describing how they would answer the multiple choice question that is given to them.<n><n><n>### Input example:<n>```<n>a: a sentence containing a multiple choice question <n>b: multiple choice answer<n><n># Output:<n>1. a sentence in a response that describes how they would answer the question.<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:Where would you dispose of a broken icebox? Choices:  A: antique store B: in the graveyard C: kitchen D: junk yard E: ice<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Where would you dispose of a old icebox? Choices A: antique store<n><n>### Demo (video):<n>[How to build a simple quiz in python](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gX3Y29gJ9s8)<n><n>## Notes:<n>- The quiz is just a way to demonstrate some fundamental concepts.<n>- If you are planning on reading the `quiz.py` file, here is the code for quiz that runs all the test cases in the file:<n>```python<n>import io, json, random<n>from sys import *<n>import pandas as pd<n>"""<n>import quiz import random<n>import json<n>import io<n>from sys import * """<n>from matplotlib import pyplot as plt<n>import tkinter as tk<n>import tkinter.messagebox as msg<n>"""<n><n>f = io.StringIO()<n>with json.writer(f, indent=4) as writer:<n>  writer.writerow(['{}:{}{}'.format(k, v) for k, v in test_cases.items()])<n>json1 = f.getvalue()<n>f.close()<n><n>d = {<n>  'test_cases': test_cases<n>}<n>json2 = json.dumps(d, indent=4)<n><n><n><n>def main():<n>  res = []<n>  res2 = []<n>  with open('quiz.json') as f:<n>    d = json.load(f)<n>    # d = json.load([f.read()])<n>    for case_num,case in enumerate(d['test_cases']):<n>      for line in case['answers']['line'].split():<n>        res.append(line)<n>      #print(res)['test_cases'][case_num].get('answers', {}).get('line'))<n><n>  with open('json.json', 'w') as f:<n>      f.write(line)<n><n><n>  if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    main()<n><n>if __name__ =='main':<n>import matplotlib.cm as cm<n>from matplotlib.colors import ListedColormap<n>from matplotlib import colors<n>from matplotlib.ticker import LinearLocator, formatStrFormatter, AutoLocator<n>from mpl_toolkits.m

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>Input: When a person is beginning work, what aren't they doing yet? Choices:  A: working B: resting C: tiredness D: accomplishing E: momentum<n>Answer: D: accomplishing<n><n>### Input:The drug kingpin told his man to run errands, this was code to go to all the dealers to do what they had? Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n><n>### Response:		A: park<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If you need money.<n><n>### Input & Output:<n><n>> A B<n>> <n>> 1st line of code:<n>* <n><n>```<n><n>	print("Enter Your choice: ")<n>	choices_number = int(input("Number of choices: "))  # this line will ask the user to enter the number of choices<n>```<n><n>* <n><n>> <n><n>```<n>	print("Choices: [A B]")<n>	while True:<n>		if (choice == 'A'):<n>			choices_number += 1<n>			print(choices_number)<n>		option = input('Answer: ')<n>		if option == 'q':<n>			break<n>		if option in choices_number:<n>			if option == choices_number[-1]:<n>				while True: # This is the for loop that will repeat what the user have done.<n>					print("I am trying to tell you... ") # Asks the user to re choose the option.<n>			else:<n>				for x in choices_number: # This is the other for loop that displays the choices<n>				    print(x)<n>				break<n>```<n><n>* Last line of code:<n><n>```<n>				if (choice_index == "A"): # This the index variable that will hold the answers<n>				      print("Well done!, your answer was option: " + x)<n>			else :<n>			      print('that isn't the answer you picked')<n>```<n><n>> C D E F G<n>><n>> <n><n>> 1st Line of Code:<n> <n>```<n>        print("Enter Your choice: A E F G") # This is the command line input that asks the user to pick a choice.<n>        choice = input('Enter the choice: ') # This is the variable that will hold the choice that the user have picked.<n>        while True:<n>            if (choice == 'A':<n>            print('You selected the answer: C')<n>            continue<n>            print('That isn't the answer')<n>            choice = input('Enter your choice: ')<n>```<n><n>
